case_title: MUSA KHAN SILACHI vs PROVINCE OF BALUCHISTAN AND ANOTHER
reference_no_or_id: Criminal Revision No. 8 of 1976, Appeal No. 13 of 1977

accussed_details.name: MUSA KHAN SILACHI
allegation: Running a bus in the name of his father
Corruption and misconduct under Government Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1973

complaint_summary: The appellant was accused of corruption and misconduct, including building large property and running a bus business under his father's name.
investigation_summary: The appellant was served a show-cause notice by the Federal Government under Government Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1973. He denied all allegations, but was compulsorily retired by the President of Pakistan without further proceedings.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal ruled that the appellant was a provincial employee, not a federal employee, and the President of Pakistan lacked the authority to retire him. The retirement order was declared ultra vires and set aside.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal allowed. Retirement order declared ultra vires.
legal_arguments: Definition of 'Civil Servant' under Civil Servants Act, 1973 and Baluchistan Civil Servants Act, 1973
Notification dated 14-9-1973 regarding All Pakistan Unified Grades
Office Memorandum issued by Establishment Division on 31st May, 1975
Provisions of the Constitution regarding provincial and federal services
assets: Large property allegedly built by appellant
Bus business allegedly run under appellant's father's name
sections: Section 2(b) of Baluchistan Civil Servants Act, 1973
key_issues: Authority of the President of Pakistan to retire provincial employees

maxims.Ultra vires: Acts beyond the legal authority of the entity performing them are invalid.

legal_terms.Civil Servant: A person employed in connection with the affairs of the Federation or a Province.

words_and_phrases.Administrative Control: Control over administrative matters, not necessarily including dismissal or retirement authority.

summary_vector_notes: The appellant, a Superintendent of Police, was compulsorily retired by the President of Pakistan under allegations of corruption and misconduct. The Tribunal ruled that the appellant was a provincial employee, not a federal employee, and the President lacked the authority to retire him. The retirement order was declared ultra vires and set aside.
